Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Situation2: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Story: I stared at the email reminder for the afternoon team meeting, my stomach twisting. The subject line—“Critical Project Updates”—made it clear this wasn’t one I could skip. My manager had already stressed the importance of everyone’s input, and I knew missing it would mean falling behind, maybe even letting the team down. But as I glanced at my phone, a text from my stepson popped up: “Are we getting the Nintendo today? You promised.” I could almost hear his hopeful voice, see the excitement in his eyes. I’d promised him, and after months of saving, today was the day. But the only time I could get to the store before it sold out was during the meeting. My partner was counting on me to keep my word, to show I was reliable, that I cared about our family’s happiness and stability. I felt pulled in two directions—between being the dependable colleague my team needed and the step-parent my family deserved. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment in my stepson’s face against the frustration of my coworkers. I sat at my desk, paralyzed, knowing I had to choose.
